Award.AwardTitle: RUI-Identification of Genes and Cellular Processes Targeted by Imprinted Pathways in Natural Variants of Arabidopsis thaliana

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although it is common knowledge that we receive half of our genes from our mother and half from our fathers, it is less widely known that the genes we inherit can play different roles depending on which parent provided them. For example, genes regulated by parental genomic imprinting (PGI) are silenced either maternally or paternally (depending on the gene) after fertilization. PGI has been characterized in mammals and seed plants, and in both cases has been linked in part to the regulation of maternal resources available to the offspring. Using the plant model Arabidopsis thaliana, it has been found that plants isolated from different regions can promote strong increases in seed size depending on whether they are used as mothers or fathers in crosses. This might further suggest that parental bias for resource allocation, or the even selection of imprinted genes themselves, is subject to variation in natural populations. This project aims to identify the genes involved in these parental effects using recombinant inbred (RI) lines, which are genetic chimeras of two initial parents, and mapping populations that carry visual markers for maternal gene expression. In addition, seed development will be characterized at the cellular level to better describe the developmental outcomes of variation in imprinted or parentally-biased systems.

Broader impacts. This project seeks to identify seed size genes that may function in short-term adaptive strategies for genomic regulation, accounting for some trait variation between Arabidopsis ascensions. This aspect is directly translatable to novel breeding strategies in agriculture. This project will also aim to advance education at the boundary of biology and mathematics. The RI lines employed are uniquely suited as a classroom tool to bridge basic genetics and physiology with computational methods. A learning module has been created to conduct publishable RI research in the Plant Genetics and Diversity course at Rhodes College. Resources will be generated from these course materials allowing educators at both the university and high school level to employ RI systems in the classroom. Educational goals will be further supported by involving undergraduate researchers at all stages of this work, and underrepresented minorities in science will continue to be actively recruited for these research projects.

Co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For centuries, breeders have correlated seed size with plant vigor, making this an important agricultural trait. Finding the ?seed size gene? is, unfortunately, no easy task because the seed is subject to parental genomic imprinting (PGI). This is a special type of gene regulation whereby a maternal gene or paternal is completely silenced. It is common knowledge that we get half of our DNA from our father and half from our mother. However, because of parental genomic imprinting and other types of gene regulation, the genes inherited from one parent?s DNA might be useless or might even be used for distinct functions. The importance of PGI is that it seems to be closely linked to embryonic resources.  PGI occurs in both seed plants and placental mammals and in both cases early experiments with imprinted genes showed that they can regulate embryo or offspring size.  Therefore, it is critical to understand PGI if we want to get beyond the limitations of traditional breeding in creating large seeds with higher oil or nutrient content to help feed the populace or lower or carbon footprint.

The plant Arabidopsis thaliana can be found throughout the Northern hemisphere.  Different variants of this species have had to adapt to a large variety of climates.  In doing so, it is expected that they have optimized resource allocation for seed size.  It had been demonstrated before that when you take plants from one environment and cross them with plants in a different environment that you can often see parental bias in progeny seed size.  For example, the German Landsberg isolate of Arabidopsis produces a large seed on American or Cape Verde Island isolates, even though the Landsberg seed it self is small.  Using the Landsberg plant as a mother can have mixed results.

The main goal of this project was to engage undergraduates in cutting edge scientific research by exploring PGI through the lens of adaptation.  We focused on two models.  The first in which two different father's pollen had similar effects on increasing seed size, but through different genetic pathways, and both by regulating maternal gene expression.  The second involved a one-sided interaction where a plant produced large seeds when pollinating, but no recipricol effects was seen.  Interestingly, this effect seemed to be mediated by the mother.  Students in the lab were able to map regions of the Arabidopsis genome responsible for these adaptive differences in seed size.  From there, several candidate genes were characterized and two were found to show a parental effect on seed size and one of these displayed the features of a parentally imprinted gene.  Further, these genes show a genetic interaction in that the loss of one gene could mask the effect of the other.  This suggests a genetic pathway that regulates seeds size as a result of adaptation. 

We also explored ways to visualize the early development of the seed during the first few days after pollination to gain insight into the cellular mechanisms responsible for seed size.  If we think about what both seed plants and placental mammals have in common, the answer would be a conduit of resources between the mother and embryo that has paternal genetic influence.  A prime target for PGI in regulating resources.  In mammals, this is the placenta.  In seed plants, this is the endosperm.  We used a combination of spectral imaging, confocal time-lapse microscope and the natural autofluorescence of the plant cell to visualize the development of the endosperm in crosses between natural variants (See image).

Finally, a portion of this project was dedicated to developing new educational modules both to bring cutting edge research to the college classroom and to bring scientific investigation to the K-12 public schools in our area.  Experimental approaches used in these projects (including whole genome DNA analysis, confocal microscopy, recombinant inbred breeding techniques and others) were piloted in the undergraduate lab to develop modules for real investigative science.  For public school outreach, we trained undergraduates to teach science modules in the local school system, we held in-service training for local educators and we developed a set of learning activities using open source software and cheap materials.  These tools were shared with local educators to build interdisciplinary learning activities in the STEM fields.
